prompt: Choose the correct sentence:
explanationTemplate: Use 'that' or 'which' for things in restrictive clauses. 'That' is more common in restrictive clauses.
exampleSentence: The movie that we watched last night was excellent.

choices.text: The movie that we watched last night was excellent.
The movie, that we watched last night, was excellent.
The movie which we watched last night, was excellent.
The movie, which we watched last night was excellent.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'The book, _____ cover is torn, needs to be replaced.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'whose' to show possession in adjective clauses. 'Whose' can refer to both people and things.
exampleSentence: The book, whose cover is torn, needs to be replaced.

prompt: Choose the correct sentence:
explanationTemplate: Use 'where' for places in adjective clauses. 'The city' refers to a location, so use 'where'.
exampleSentence: Tokyo is the city where I was born.

choices.text: Tokyo is the city which I was born.
Tokyo is the city where I was born.
Tokyo is the city that I was born.
Tokyo is the city who I was born.

prompt: Choose the correct sentence:
explanationTemplate: Use 'whom' (or 'who' in informal English) for people as objects in adjective clauses. 'The teacher' is the object of 'met'.
exampleSentence: The teacher whom I met yesterday is very experienced.

choices.text: The teacher which I met yesterday is very experienced.
The teacher who I met yesterday is very experienced.
The teacher whom I met yesterday is very experienced.
The teacher that I met yesterday, is very experienced.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'The reason _____ I called you is important.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'why' for reasons in adjective clauses. 'The reason' refers to why something happened.
exampleSentence: The reason why I called you is important.

prompt: Combine the sentences: 'He studied hard. He passed the exam.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'so' or 'therefore' to show cause and effect. 'So' is more common in informal English.
exampleSentence: He studied hard, so he passed the exam.

choices.text: He studied hard, he passed the exam.
He studied hard, so he passed the exam.
He studied hard. So he passed the exam.
He studied hard so he passed the exam.

prompt: Combine the sentences: 'She loves music. She can't play any instrument.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'but' or 'however' to show contrast. 'But' is more common and doesn't need a comma before it when connecting two independent clauses.
exampleSentence: She loves music, but she can't play any instrument.

choices.text: She loves music, but she can't play any instrument.
She loves music, she can't play any instrument.
She loves music. But she can't play any instrument.
She loves music but, she can't play any instrument.

prompt: Combine the sentences: 'I was late. I still caught the train.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'but' or 'however' to show unexpected contrast. 'But' connects the clauses directly.
exampleSentence: I was late, but I still caught the train.

choices.text: I was late, I still caught the train.
I was late. But I still caught the train.
I was late, but I still caught the train.
I was late but, I still caught the train.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'I wanted to go to the party, _____ I had too much work.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'but' to show contrast between two ideas. 'But' connects contrasting clauses.
exampleSentence: I wanted to go to the party, but I had too much work.

prompt: Choose the correct pronoun: 'Between you and _____, I think this is a bad idea.'
explanationTemplate: Use object pronouns (me, you, him, her, us, them) after prepositions like 'between'. 'Between you and me' is correct.
exampleSentence: Between you and me, I think this is a bad idea.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'The students should do the homework _____.'
explanationTemplate: Use reflexive pronouns (myself, yourself, himself, herself, itself, ourselves, yourselves, themselves) when the subject and object are the same.
exampleSentence: The students should do the homework themselves.

prompt: Choose the correct pronoun: 'Everyone should bring _____ own lunch.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'his or her' (or 'their' in modern English) with 'everyone'. 'Everyone' is singular, so traditionally use 'his or her'.
exampleSentence: Everyone should bring his or her own lunch.

prompt: Choose the correct pronoun: 'Neither of the students brought _____ book.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'his or her' (or 'their' in modern English) with 'neither of'. 'Neither' is singular.
exampleSentence: Neither of the students brought his or her book.

prompt: Choose the correct sentence:
explanationTemplate: Use 'who' for people as subjects in relative clauses. 'The doctor' is a person and the subject, so use 'who'.
exampleSentence: The doctor who treated me was very kind.

choices.text: The doctor who treated me was very kind.
The doctor which treated me was very kind.
The doctor that treated me, was very kind.
The doctor whom treated me was very kind.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'The company _____ I work is very large.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'where' for places in relative clauses. 'The company' refers to a place (location), so use 'where'.
exampleSentence: The company where I work is very large.

prompt: Choose the correct sentence:
explanationTemplate: Use 'which' for non-restrictive clauses (with commas). 'That' cannot be used with commas.
exampleSentence: My car, which is red, needs to be washed.

choices.text: My car, that is red, needs to be washed.
My car, which is red, needs to be washed.
My car which is red, needs to be washed.
My car, which is red needs to be washed.

prompt: Choose the correct article: 'I saw _____ interesting movie yesterday.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'an' before words starting with a vowel sound. 'Interesting' starts with a vowel sound.
exampleSentence: I saw an interesting movie yesterday.

prompt: Choose the correct form: 'A number of students _____ absent today.'
explanationTemplate: 'A number of' is plural, so use 'are'. 'The number of' would be singular.
exampleSentence: A number of students are absent today.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'The new bridge _____ being built next year.'
explanationTemplate: Use future passive: 'will be + past participle'. 'Will be being' is not used; use 'will be + past participle' instead.
exampleSentence: The new bridge will be built next year.

prompt: Convert to reported speech: 'I can help you,' she said.
explanationTemplate: In reported speech, 'can' becomes 'could'. Present modals change to past modals.
exampleSentence: She said that she could help me.

choices.text: She said that she can help me.
She said that she could help me.
She said that she will help me.

prompt: Choose the correct sentence:
explanationTemplate: Use 'that' or 'which' for things. In restrictive clauses, 'that' is preferred. No comma needed.
exampleSentence: The song that I heard yesterday was beautiful.

choices.text: The song that I heard yesterday was beautiful.
The song, that I heard yesterday, was beautiful.
The song which I heard yesterday, was beautiful.
The song, which I heard yesterday was beautiful.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'The day _____ I met you was the best day of my life.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'when' for time in adjective clauses. 'The day' refers to a time, so use 'when'.
exampleSentence: The day when I met you was the best day of my life.

prompt: Choose the correct sentence:
explanationTemplate: Use 'whom' (or 'who' in informal English) for people as objects. 'The actor' is the object of 'admire'.
exampleSentence: The actor whom I admire most is very talented.

choices.text: The actor which I admire most is very talented.
The actor who I admire most is very talented.
The actor whom I admire most is very talented.
The actor that I admire most, is very talented.

prompt: Combine the sentences: 'I was hungry. I ate a sandwich.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'so' to show cause and effect. 'So' connects the reason and the result.
exampleSentence: I was hungry, so I ate a sandwich.

choices.text: I was hungry, I ate a sandwich.
I was hungry, so I ate a sandwich.
I was hungry. So I ate a sandwich.
I was hungry so I ate a sandwich.

prompt: Combine the sentences: 'She studied all night. She was still tired in the morning.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'but' to show unexpected contrast. 'But' connects contrasting ideas.
exampleSentence: She studied all night, but she was still tired in the morning.

choices.text: She studied all night, but she was still tired in the morning.
She studied all night, she was still tired in the morning.
She studied all night. But she was still tired in the morning.
She studied all night but, she was still tired in the morning.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'I wanted to watch the movie, _____ I had to finish my homework first.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'but' to show contrast between what you want and what you must do.
exampleSentence: I wanted to watch the movie, but I had to finish my homework first.

prompt: Choose the correct pronoun: 'The teacher gave the students _____ homework.'
explanationTemplate: Use possessive pronouns (my, your, his, her, its, our, their) to show ownership. 'Students' is plural, so use 'their'.
exampleSentence: The teacher gave the students their homework.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'She cut _____ while cooking.'
explanationTemplate: Use reflexive pronouns when the subject and object are the same. 'She' cut 'herself'.
exampleSentence: She cut herself while cooking.

prompt: Choose the correct pronoun: 'Both of the students finished _____ assignments.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'their' with 'both of' because 'both' refers to multiple people. 'Both' is plural.
exampleSentence: Both of the students finished their assignments.

prompt: Choose the correct sentence:
explanationTemplate: Use 'who' for people as subjects. 'The writer' is a person and the subject, so use 'who'.
exampleSentence: The writer who wrote this novel is very famous.

choices.text: The writer who wrote this novel is very famous.
The writer which wrote this novel is very famous.
The writer that wrote this novel, is very famous.
The writer whom wrote this novel is very famous.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'The restaurant _____ we had dinner was expensive.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'where' for places in relative clauses. 'The restaurant' refers to a location, so use 'where'.
exampleSentence: The restaurant where we had dinner was expensive.

prompt: Choose the correct sentence:
explanationTemplate: Use 'which' for non-restrictive clauses (with commas). 'That' cannot be used with commas.
exampleSentence: My laptop, which I bought last year, is already slow.

choices.text: My laptop, that I bought last year, is already slow.
My laptop, which I bought last year, is already slow.
My laptop which I bought last year, is already slow.
My laptop, which I bought last year is already slow.

prompt: Choose the correct article: 'I need _____ umbrella because it's raining.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'an' before words starting with a vowel sound. 'Umbrella' starts with a vowel sound.
exampleSentence: I need an umbrella because it's raining.

prompt: Fill in the blank: '_____ Pacific Ocean is the largest ocean.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'the' with unique geographical features like oceans, seas, rivers, and mountain ranges.
exampleSentence: The Pacific Ocean is the largest ocean.

prompt: Choose the correct article: 'I love _____ coffee in the morning.'
explanationTemplate: Use no article with uncountable nouns when speaking in general. 'Coffee' is uncountable and general here.
exampleSentence: I love coffee in the morning.

prompt: Choose the correct form: 'Either the teacher or the students _____ wrong.'
explanationTemplate: With 'either...or', the verb agrees with the subject closest to it. 'Students' is plural, so use 'are'.
exampleSentence: Either the teacher or the students are wrong.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'The team _____ celebrating their victory.'
explanationTemplate: 'Team' can be singular (as a group) or plural (as individuals). Here it's treated as singular, so use 'is'.
exampleSentence: The team is celebrating their victory.

prompt: Choose the correct form: 'Each of the students _____ a different book.'
explanationTemplate: 'Each of' is singular, so use 'has' (not 'have'). 'Each' always takes a singular verb.
exampleSentence: Each of the students has a different book.

prompt: Convert to passive voice: 'The chef cooked a delicious meal.'
explanationTemplate: Passive voice: be + past participle. The object becomes the subject, and the original subject becomes optional (with 'by').
exampleSentence: A delicious meal was cooked by the chef.

choices.text: The chef was cooked a delicious meal.
A delicious meal was cooked by the chef.
A delicious meal cooked by the chef.
A delicious meal is cooking by the chef.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'The problem _____ solved by the team yesterday.'
explanationTemplate: Use past tense 'was' (singular) or 'were' (plural) + past participle for passive voice in the past.
exampleSentence: The problem was solved by the team yesterday.

prompt: Convert to passive voice: 'They are building a new school.'
explanationTemplate: Use present continuous passive: 'is/are being + past participle'. 'They are building' becomes 'A new school is being built'.
exampleSentence: A new school is being built.

choices.text: A new school is being built.

prompt: Convert to reported speech: 'I have been waiting for an hour,' he said.
explanationTemplate: In reported speech, present perfect continuous becomes past perfect continuous. 'I have been waiting' becomes 'he had been waiting'.
exampleSentence: He said that he had been waiting for an hour.

choices.text: He said that he has been waiting for an hour.
He said that he is waiting for an hour.
He said that he had been waiting for an hour.
He said he waits for an hour.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'I will call you later,' she said. â†’ She said that she _____ call me later.
explanationTemplate: In reported speech, 'will' becomes 'would'. Future tense changes to conditional.
exampleSentence: She said that she would call me later.

prompt: Convert to reported speech: 'What time is it?' he asked.
explanationTemplate: Questions in reported speech use 'asked' and change word order. 'What time is it?' becomes 'he asked what time it was'.
exampleSentence: He asked what time it was.

choices.text: He asked what time is it.
He asked what time it was.
He asked what time was it.
He asked what time it is.

prompt: Choose the correct preposition: 'I will see you _____ Monday.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'on' for specific days of the week. 'Monday' is a specific day, so use 'on'.
exampleSentence: I will see you on Monday.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'She is afraid _____ spiders.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'afraid of' (not 'afraid from' or 'afraid about'). 'Of' follows 'afraid'.
exampleSentence: She is afraid of spiders.

prompt: Choose the correct preposition: 'I'm looking forward _____ meeting you.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'look forward to + noun/gerund'. 'To' is a preposition here, so it's followed by a noun or gerund.
exampleSentence: I'm looking forward to meeting you.

prompt: Choose the correct modal: 'You _____ not enter without permission.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'must not' to express prohibition. 'Must not' means something is not allowed.
exampleSentence: You must not enter without permission.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'She _____ have left already. Her car is gone.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'must have + past participle' to express a logical conclusion about a past event. The evidence suggests she left.
exampleSentence: She must have left already. Her car is gone.

prompt: Choose the correct form: 'If I _____ enough money, I would buy a new car.'
explanationTemplate: This is a second conditional. Use simple past in the if-clause for hypothetical present situations.
exampleSentence: If I had enough money, I would buy a new car.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'If she _____ studied harder, she would have passed.'
explanationTemplate: This is a third conditional. Use 'had + past participle' in the if-clause for past hypothetical situations.
exampleSentence: If she had studied harder, she would have passed.

prompt: Choose the correct form: 'I _____ working on this project for three hours.'
explanationTemplate: Use present perfect continuous (have/has been + verb-ing) for actions that started in the past and continue to now.
exampleSentence: I have been working on this project for three hours.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'By next year, I _____ living here for five years.'
explanationTemplate: Use future perfect continuous (will have been + verb-ing) for actions that will continue up to a future time.
exampleSentence: By next year, I will have been living here for five years.

prompt: Choose the correct sentence:
explanationTemplate: Use 'that' or 'which' for things in restrictive clauses. 'That' is preferred in restrictive clauses.
exampleSentence: The phone that I bought yesterday is already broken.

choices.text: The phone that I bought yesterday is already broken.
The phone, that I bought yesterday, is already broken.
The phone which I bought yesterday, is already broken.
The phone, which I bought yesterday is already broken.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'The reason _____ she left is still unknown.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'why' for reasons in adjective clauses. 'The reason' refers to why something happened.
exampleSentence: The reason why she left is still unknown.

prompt: Choose the correct sentence:
explanationTemplate: Use 'whom' (or 'who' in informal English) for people as objects. 'The professor' is the object of 'respect'.
exampleSentence: The professor whom I respect most is retiring this year.

choices.text: The professor which I respect most is retiring this year.
The professor whom I respect most is retiring this year.
The professor who I respect most, is retiring this year.
The professor that I respect most, is retiring this year.

prompt: Choose the correct sentence:
explanationTemplate: Use 'whose' to show possession in adjective clauses. 'Whose' can refer to both people and things.
exampleSentence: The company whose profits increased is expanding.

choices.text: The company whose profits increased is expanding.
The company which profits increased is expanding.
The company that profits increased is expanding.
The company who profits increased is expanding.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'The moment _____ I saw her, I knew she was special.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'when' for time in adjective clauses. 'The moment' refers to a time, so use 'when'.
exampleSentence: The moment when I saw her, I knew she was special.

prompt: Choose the correct pronoun: 'The book is _____, not yours.'
explanationTemplate: Use possessive pronouns (mine, yours, his, hers, ours, theirs) to show ownership without a noun. 'Mine' means 'my book'.
exampleSentence: The book is mine, not yours.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'One should always do _____ best.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'one's' (possessive form of 'one') when using 'one' as a pronoun. 'One' is formal and singular.
exampleSentence: One should always do one's best.

prompt: Choose the correct pronoun: 'The children enjoyed _____ at the park.'
explanationTemplate: Use reflexive pronouns when the subject and object are the same. 'The children' enjoyed 'themselves'.
exampleSentence: The children enjoyed themselves at the park.

prompt: Choose the correct pronoun: 'Nobody brought _____ own lunch.'
explanationTemplate: In modern English, 'their' is commonly used with 'nobody', 'everyone', 'someone' etc., even though these are technically singular.
exampleSentence: Nobody brought their own lunch.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'I made this cake _____.'
explanationTemplate: Use reflexive pronouns when the subject and object are the same. 'I' made it 'myself'.
exampleSentence: I made this cake myself.

prompt: Combine the sentences: 'The weather was bad. We decided to stay home.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'so' to show cause and effect. 'So' connects the reason and the result.
exampleSentence: The weather was bad, so we decided to stay home.

choices.text: The weather was bad, we decided to stay home.
The weather was bad, so we decided to stay home.
The weather was bad. So we decided to stay home.
The weather was bad so we decided to stay home.

prompt: Combine the sentences: 'He failed the exam. He didn't study enough.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'because' to show cause and effect. 'Because' explains the reason.
exampleSentence: He failed the exam because he didn't study enough.

choices.text: He failed the exam because he didn't study enough.
He failed the exam, he didn't study enough.
He failed the exam. Because he didn't study enough.
He failed the exam because, he didn't study enough.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'I like coffee, _____ my friend prefers tea.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'but' to show contrast between two different preferences or opinions.
exampleSentence: I like coffee, but my friend prefers tea.

prompt: Combine the sentences: 'She was very tired. She continued working.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'although' or 'even though' to show unexpected contrast. 'Although' introduces the contrasting idea.
exampleSentence: Although she was very tired, she continued working.

choices.text: She was very tired, she continued working.
Although she was very tired, she continued working.
She was very tired. Although she continued working.
She was very tired although, she continued working.

prompt: Choose the correct article: 'I saw _____ owl in the tree.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'an' before words starting with a vowel sound. 'Owl' starts with a vowel sound.
exampleSentence: I saw an owl in the tree.

prompt: Fill in the blank: '_____ United States is a large country.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'the' with country names that are plural or include words like 'United', 'Kingdom', 'Republic'.
exampleSentence: The United States is a large country.

prompt: Choose the correct article: 'I need _____ information about this topic.'
explanationTemplate: Use no article with uncountable nouns when speaking in general. 'Information' is uncountable and general here.
exampleSentence: I need information about this topic.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'She is _____ honest person.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'an' before words starting with a vowel sound. 'Honest' starts with a vowel sound (silent 'h').
exampleSentence: She is an honest person.

prompt: Choose the correct form: 'The news _____ very surprising.'
explanationTemplate: 'News' is always singular, even though it ends with 's'. Use 'is' (not 'are').
exampleSentence: The news is very surprising.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'Not only the teacher but also the students _____ excited.'
explanationTemplate: With 'not only...but also', the verb agrees with the subject closest to it. 'Students' is plural, so use 'are'.
exampleSentence: Not only the teacher but also the students are excited.

prompt: Choose the correct form: 'Mathematics _____ my favorite subject.'
explanationTemplate: Subjects ending in '-ics' (mathematics, physics, economics) are usually singular. Use 'is'.
exampleSentence: Mathematics is my favorite subject.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'The group of students _____ waiting outside.'
explanationTemplate: 'The group of' is singular, so use 'is'. The prepositional phrase 'of students' doesn't change the subject.
exampleSentence: The group of students is waiting outside.

prompt: Convert to passive voice: 'The students cleaned the classroom.'
explanationTemplate: Passive voice: be + past participle. The object becomes the subject, and the original subject becomes optional (with 'by').
exampleSentence: The classroom was cleaned by the students.

choices.text: The students were cleaned the classroom.
The classroom cleaned by the students.
The classroom was cleaned by the students.
The classroom is cleaning by the students.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'The report _____ written by the team last week.'
explanationTemplate: Use past tense 'was' (singular) or 'were' (plural) + past participle for passive voice in the past.
exampleSentence: The report was written by the team last week.

prompt: Convert to passive voice: 'Someone has stolen my wallet.'
explanationTemplate: Use present perfect passive: 'has/have been + past participle'. 'Has stolen' becomes 'has been stolen'.
exampleSentence: My wallet has been stolen.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'The windows _____ cleaned every week.'
explanationTemplate: Use simple present passive: 'is/are + past participle'. 'Windows' is plural, so use 'are'.
exampleSentence: The windows are cleaned every week.

prompt: Convert to reported speech: 'I can speak three languages,' she said.
explanationTemplate: In reported speech, 'can' becomes 'could'. Present modals change to past modals.
exampleSentence: She said that she could speak three languages.

choices.text: She said that she can speak three languages.
She said that she could speak three languages.
She said that she will speak three languages.
She said she speaks three languages.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'I'm leaving now,' he said. â†’ He said that he _____ leaving then.
explanationTemplate: In reported speech, present continuous becomes past continuous. 'I'm leaving' becomes 'he was leaving'. Also, 'now' becomes 'then'.
exampleSentence: He said that he was leaving then.

prompt: Convert to reported speech: 'Where do you live?' she asked.
explanationTemplate: Questions in reported speech use 'asked' and change word order. 'Where do you live?' becomes 'she asked where I lived'.
exampleSentence: She asked where I lived.

choices.text: She asked where do I live.
She asked where did I live.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'I saw him yesterday,' she said. â†’ She said that she _____ seen him the day before.
explanationTemplate: In reported speech, simple past becomes past perfect. 'I saw' becomes 'she had seen'. Also, 'yesterday' becomes 'the day before'.
exampleSentence: She said that she had seen him the day before.

prompt: Choose the correct sentence:
explanationTemplate: Use 'who' for people as subjects. 'The singer' is a person and the subject, so use 'who'.
exampleSentence: The singer who performed last night was amazing.

choices.text: The singer who performed last night was amazing.
The singer which performed last night was amazing.
The singer that performed last night, was amazing.
The singer whom performed last night was amazing.

prompt: Fill in the blank: 'The house _____ I grew up is now demolished.'
explanationTemplate: Use 'where' for places in relative clauses. 'The house' refers to a location, so use 'where'.
exampleSentence: The house where I grew up is now demolished.

prompt: Choose the correct sentence:
explanationTemplate: Use 'which' for non-restrictive clauses (with commas). 'That' cannot be used with commas.
exampleSentence: My phone, which I bought last month, is already broken.

choices.text: My phone, that I bought last month, is already broken.
My phone, which I bought last month, is already broken.
My phone which I bought last month, is already broken.
My phone, which I bought last month is already broken.
